p.s: In the following it is going to be analysed howShakespeare makes use of poetic and formal devices to intensify and illustrate his view.
beginning with a formal aspects one can say that this sonnet is a typical Shakespearean sonnet.
It has 14 lines and is devideddivided into three quatrains and an ending couplet.
The first twelve lines are cross rhymes (abab cdcd efef) and the couplet consists of a pair rhyme (gg).
A typical device for a Shakespearean sonnet is the iambic pentameter, which means that the verse starts with an unstressed syllable, followed by a stressed one.
In a sentence are five unstressed and five stressed syllables.
This makes the sonnet emotional, because it sounds like a heartbeat.
The turning point, the so called Volta is located in l. 9 But.
The first poetic device takes place in l. 2, which is aan antithesis I do believe her, though I know she lies.
This stands for the trust of the person to the female persons though he knows that she is a liar.
The effect on the eeader is that the conflict yets underlined by saying that he believes her still.

Furthermore the author employs a rhetorical question in l. 9 But wherefore says she not she is unjust? It makes clear that it would be unlogical, when she says that she is a liar or unjust, because it throws a bad light on herself.
The rhetorical question arranges that the reader gets directly addressed and also gets influenced.
Moreover, the next sentence is also a rhetorical question in l. 10 And wherefore say not I that I am old?.
This means that he/she questions his/herself, why he dodoes not tell the trust about his age.
A direct address gets created again.
The reader feels influenced, because of the question.
The repetition of the word wherefore in ll. 9-10 But wherefore says she not she is unjust?And wherefore say not I that I am old? shows his train of thought.
The author does this to enrich the meaning of the two questions.
Besides, the author utilizes a metaphor in l. 6 Although she knows my days are past the best.
He explains that his best time is ago and that he collected experiences.
This creates an image in the mind of the reader.
By making use of an antithesis, it is said that the lyrical eye gives her still credits, though she lies with him (l. 7).
This antithesis underlines the conflict that he believes her, though she lies.
And wherefore say not I that I am old? [...] And age in love loves not to have years told is an anaphora in ll. 10-12.
The author wants to explain that the age does not play a major role in a relationship.
The effect on the reader is that this anaphora emphasizes a thought.
All in all one can say that aShakespeare wants to intensify his views with antithesis, repititiong rhetorical questions, anaphoras and metaphors.
He wants to express that two persons have to trust the other person and that age is not important in a relationship.
